contentrichtext.text: {{Other uses|N11 (disambiguation)}} An '''N11 code''' or '''N11 number''' (said as n-one-one) is a special [[abbreviated dialing]] [[telephone number]] within the [[North American Numbering Plan]], which allows access to special [[Service (economics)|service]]s. Each of these eight numbers prevents 10,000 telephone numbers (from N11-0000 to N11-9999) from being used. Only non-[[geographic]] [[area code]]s, such as [[toll-free telephone number|toll-free]] 800/888/877/866/855 numbers and [[900 number]]s may use N11 as the [[telephone exchange]] [[Telephone prefix|prefix]], since the area code must always be dialed for these numbers. Usage is generally assigned as follows: *[[2-1-1]]: [[community]] services, [[United Way of America|United Way]] *[[3-1-1]]: [[municipal government]] services, non-emergency *[[4-1-1]]: [[directory assistance]] *[[5-1-1]]: [[traffic]] [[information]] or police non-emergency services *[[6-1-1]]: [[telephone company|telephone company (telco)]] [[customer service]] and repair *[[7-1-1]]: [[Telecommunications devices for the deaf|TDD]] [[Telecommunications Relay Service|relay]] for the [[deaf]] *[[8-1-1]]: underground public [[utility location]],<ref>See FCC Doc. [http://fjallfoss.fcc.gov/edocs_public/attachmatch/DOC-257293A1.doc No. 92-105]</ref> in Canada 8-1-1 is assigned for non-emergency health information and services *[[9-1-1]] emergency medical, police, or fire 9-1-1 and 4-1-1 work from nearly every telephone in the [[United States|U.S.]] and [[Canada]], while the others vary from place to place. Generally, only 4-1-1 calls incur a fee. 9-1-1 access is mandated by [[law]], even on lines with no service (a "soft" [[dial tone]]). 6-1-1 (formerly 8-1-1) may also be accessible to activate service on such lines, and 3-1-1 may be available as well for urgent (but non-emergency) calls to [[police]], or any call to local government in some places. Other community services are provided through 2-1-1, but only if a [[non-profit]] organization such as the [[United Way of America|United Way]] operates it locally. Likewise, local or state/provincial government may or may not operate traffic information through 5-1-1. 8-1-1 was made mandatory in the U.S. in 2007, as is 7-1-1. Unlike 9-1-1, these may or may not be available on a phone without paid service. [[0-1-1]] followed by a [[country code]] is used to dial internationally, but this use is not considered an N11 code. 1-1-1 is not available in the NANP, because 11 is the prefix used to access [[vertical service code]]s from [[rotary phone]]s, and is essentially meaningless to the system otherwise. ==See also== *[[Single Non-Emergency Number]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://answers.usa.gov/cgi-bin/gsa_ict.cfg/php/enduser/std_adp.php?p_faqid=7166 USA.gov FAQ on Use of N11 Service Codes] *[http://www.nanpa.com/number_resource_info/n11_codes.html NANPA N11 Codes Assignment] *[http://www.cnac.ca/other_codes/n11/n11_codes.htm Administered N11 Codes in Canada] *[http://www.wutc.wa.gov/webimage.nsf/0/6BAE8B60551EFE1688257123005E3A7F N11 as Regulated and Implemented in Washington State] *[http://www.ca.gov/n11/ The N11 Service Directory of California] {{N11_codes|state=uncollapsed}} {{Emergency telephone numbers|state=uncollapsed}} [[Category:North American Numbering Plan]]
